"Hope is the medicine Of the soul, the cor


dial which anmates and sustains us under
she labours of life, which alevistes the se-
verest Affections, and which sheds an in
creased splendour over the fairest day Of
earthly prosperity. But the best hopes,
which take their rise only from this world,
and whose flight is restricted within the
narrow range Of earthly good are totally in
adequate to allay the fear of death, and to
remove; or in any measure to mitigate, some
OF the heaviest suff'erings. to which we are
mere subjected. There are disappointments,
which this world cannot compensate; losses,
!or which it can afford no substitute; sor-
rows, to which it brings no alleviation.


would not deny the value and excellence
ef the nature, which God has given me, OF
Ne capacity for Improvement and useful
ness, with which he has cndued me, and the
,,nnumerable sources of qualification and de-
,,lsht, to which he offers me access. ac-
knowledge with gratitude the multiplied
earthly blessings, on his part so undeserved,
which he bestows on me. l am enchanted
with the beauty and splendour, and magnif-
Sehce OF the world in which he has placed
'l,, ane, l rejoice in the fertility of the earth


"llch SO abundantly rewards the labours Of
,,aan, and supplies subsistence for the count
cnissss nss', myrlads of its children. contemplate

THE CHRISTIANS HOPE.

than the Curate giving one convulsive shud-
der, fell senseless on the Altar. All was
now copfusion-the ceremony was not half
finished, and the Minister was laying sense
less-every means was now used to recover
him, but for some time without effect. At
length he slowly opened his eyes, and the
first object he saw was Louisa Mordaunt,
bending over, him, her looks expressive ofthe
utmost compassion for his situation. This
had almost again plunged him into forgetful-
ness and it was only by very strong effort
that he succeeded in raising himself; he
then, by great exertions, succeeded in finish
ing the ceremony, at the end of which he a.
gain became senseless, and was i'll this state
conveyed home.


He did not long survive the marriage of
Louisa Mordaunt, he soon after died vic
tim OF that worst of all diseases-a broken
heart Louisa Mordaunt lived long and
happily with whom she made her husband
nor did she ever surmise the dreadful effect
her marriage had upon the Rev. Alfred Cor
sar. ]. H.

I would fain hear from those marriage
haters but shadow of reason. why | should
not pronounce a modest wife the greatest Of
human blessings. She is the safety of that
house whose affairs she administers. She is
the tender and faithful love Of your children.
She is the JOY of your health, and your care
and relief in sickness, the partner of your
good fortune and comfort in your bad. She
sooths and breaks the headlong violence of
youth, and tempers the morose austerity of
age. Will any one offer to persuade US that
the education of children, which are the ve-
ry images of our bodies and pictures oi our
minds and in whom we see as it were our
very selves born again anew, affords not a
delight since to the last degree' or that is no
satisfaction when we come to obey the laws
of fate, to see son OF our own to whom e
can bequeath those honours and posse ssions
of our families which we received from our
parents.
MARRIAGE.

employed on some expedition an Indian to
Carry his baggage. Ofnis he was instantly
accused, and condemnGd to suffer the pun
ishment enacted for the offence, which was
to be publicly whipped on an ass. Great
intercession was made for him, but without
effect. After many solicitations, however,
respite for fortnight was obtained from the
governor; but just as this reached the prison
the criminal was stript, and mounted, and
exhibited for punishment. On hearing Of
the respite he said. Nay. the shame is suf-
fered; worse cannot be done; therefore, ex-
ecntioner, discharge your duty, and return
the tyrant his reprieve.' The sentence ac-
cordingly took its course, and the young
man endured it with the greatest cslmncss;
but he never after could lie brought t. asso-
ciate with gentlemen. He was constantly
wandering about by himself in a state Of
gloomy melancholy, and stunning the soci-
ETY. and converse of his fellow creatures.


Soon after the Governor was removed,
and another person sent in his stead, but A.
auirra was still seen to hover about the
palace. The Governors friends apprehen-
withdraw to some other place, he did SO,
and went to Los Reyes, three hundred and
twenty leagues from thence; but in a weeks
time Aqyirra was there, having followed
him on foot. The Viceroy then removed as
secretly as he could to Quito, which is four
hundred leagues from Los Reyes; there also
cane Aquirra in a short space oftime, tho
he travelled as before, without shoe& or
stockings. Finding himself SO closely pur-
sued, the Governor took another flight as
far as Cusco, which is FIVE hundred leagues
from Quito, but there also he was followed
by Aqurra. Being wearied by so. many
journeys, the Governor said, Il will fly the
villain no longer, but keep a guard about ms
and defy him;' which he did !; bat the gates
being one day open, and all the servants en-
gagged in play, Aquirra entered, and find
ing his enemy alone, stabbed him to the heart
and then despatched himself with the same
dagger.

THE LANGUAGE OF THE EYES.
There is 4 brightness IN the beam
That darts electric from the eyes,
Softer and dearer than the CLEAN
ORAL that's radient in the skies.
II holds DER every mind control;
II bows each passion to IT'S shrine,
And 6resat once the impassioned soul
Toac.ions generous and divine.
1t language all can speak;
4 tongue all nations understands
o'c, .spland's mountains chill and bleak,
And Ger Arabia's burning sand.
IT is the language foemen speak,
In battles hour Of strife and death;
The peaderfor the dumb and weak,
More powerful far than human breath.
'Tis that which Youthful heroes speak,
when burning blood darts through their veinsi
II is the PATRIOTS, when his check
'.antles TO flame at thought Of cllansi
TIL, lover, when he speaks the tn ought
That bids the maidens bosom rise
Wiz power, with fire, with sweetness iraught,
II is the language q the eyes.

TuELANGuAGE OF THE EYES.

Cold as the grave can make if
That faithful heart must be,
Whose light would not forsakeit
In parting thus from thee.
When hand in hand is warmly prest,
Alasl who docs not know,
That tears swell high in many breast
Too proud to let them flow.
Go--and may every sorrow
BE distant FROM thy way,
And every new tomorrow
Be happier than to-day
My sunshine smile through every storm,
And rainbows through the showers,
While thy mild heaven is clear and warm,
And never cold like ours.
IF innocence and beauty
Concliate human love,
thigh regard for duty
Can find friend above,
No power thy pleasures can destroy,
While love or friendship lives,
And will ask no purer Joy
Than this remembrance gives.

"d DAB at any IHing."-A dab is consid-
cred to be a mere corruption of the word
adeht, which signifies person far advanc-
ed or perfect in any thing, and is no other
than the word adehtns In the same way a
cute man is the abbreviation of acute, or the
Latin acutus, and signifies person that Is
sharp, clever, neat; or to use more modern
term, an feh, at the subject you happen to
be speaking of.


us Dead as Herriag."--The herring
is delicate fish, which is killed by very
small degree of violence. Whenever it is
taken cut the water, even though it seem to
have received no hurt, it gives squeak, and
Immediately expires; and though it be
thrown instantly back into the water it new
er receives. Hence arises the proverb, "as
dead as herring


"Steehs like Toh."--This we may see
in familiar language of a person completely
under the influence of Morpheus; and we
generally imagine the simile taken from the
momentarv pause of peg-top, or huinming
top, when its rotary motion is at the height.
But no such thing, the werd top is Italian.
Toto, in that language, signifies mouse, 1t
is the generic name, and applied indiscriln-
nately to the common mouse, field mouse,
and dormous, from which the Italian prov
erb, "Ef dorme come an toho" is derived;
Ang};cr, "He clecrs like top"


"Hiac Men d Gotham. ."-Gotham is a
village in Noting ghamshire. Its Magistrates
are said to have attempted to hedge in a
cuckoo; and bush called the Cuckoo's bush,
is still shown in support Of the tradition. A
thousand other ridiculous stories are told Of
the Men of Gotham.


"2rue Blue ner,er Stain. ."--Coventry had
formerly the reputation for dyeing blues; in
somuch that true Blue came to be- proverb,
to signify one who was always the same,
like and himself.


ITO 1Aro7v the Gaatlet"-A proverbitl
phrase sgnifying to challenge or tlefv. The
expression derives its origin from the days
Of c ivalry, when he that challenged an OPP
ponent in the list threw down his glove, and
he that accepted the challenge took it up
The word is Fr, nch, and comes from gand
or gant, glove" The gantlct was in use
before the thirteenth century.


"7o Ran tie Gantlohe.nn-A proverbia
phrase commonly expressed to run the CANT
let, and signfying primarily, a certain mill
itary punishment, and fguratively, the pass
ing through difficulties. According to ths
erroneous pronunciation, the hearcr who
compares this phrase with that which is the
subject of the preceding article, is much al
loss to understand the word gantlef. The
real words are these, "to run the Client
race" Gtent Gauut or Cant is a we'll
known town III Flanders; and iooh in the
Belsic signifies race. The gantlope, oil
Ghent.race, so called because invented al
that place, is this: In the land service whel
soldier is to be punished in this manner
the regiment is drawn out in two ranks, IA
eng ach ether, and each soldier having 3
switch in his hand, lashes the criminal as he
runs along naked from the waist upwards
In the navy, the whole ships crew is dis
posed in two rows, standing face to face, OF
both sides Of the deck, SO as to form line
whereby the delinquent may so forward or
one side and return aft on the other; ant
each seaman being furnished with small
twisted cord, strikes him as he passes.

Kindly blow, thou ftfill breeze!


Onward roll, thou briny billowi
O'cr the wide and tracklcss seas.


Speed thy course. my gallant U{iloac
Merry landsmsn, free from cares,


Far from din or dread of danger,
Reck MT ofthe toll he bears


Cccan's lorn and lonely ranger
Sport Of whirlwinds giddy breath.


Now on liquid mountains riding,
Forms Of horror, shapes Of death,


Billow, blast and beach bestriding,
Banist'(l far from woman's smile


Smile-the sweetest after sorrow
Far from loves cndearing vile,


Festive eve, and .jocund morrow.
Where The buoyant schooncrridcs,


Perils every track pursuing,
Arms the tempest, swells the tide,


Points the crasgy cliffs with ruin.
Merry landsmen, free from cares,


Far from din or dread Of danger,
Little reck the toll he bears,


Oceans iorn and lonely ranger.
Selected for Tie Ultmingtonian.

"oh, mountain streams must ioveler be,
Which, where their waters rise,


Spring On immediate to the sea,


Scarce shown to mortal eyes:


Than those which glide with clouded tide,
Slow o'cT the wastes of earth,


Nor keep one trace of that hign place.


Which gave their pure waves birth"
Mr.. Granville had but recently settled in
Roxborough. and was about commencing
business with aattering prospects of success,
when he was suddenly prostrated by vio-
lent disease against which the natural
strength of his constitution. though in the
prime and yigor of his days, afforded but a
feeble defence. He died the sixth day after
the attack-and they buried him in quiet
corner of the village churchyard, beneath
the shade of young willow, and, as it was
in summer, the fresh turf with which they
decked his grave, soon exhibited a luxurant
vegetation.


A wife and two lovely children were left
behind; and they who have felt what such
bereavement is, alone know something of the
bitterness of the trial which that widowed
mother was called to endure--and to en-
tlure alone; for her infant orphans were too
young to know the full amount of the loss
they had sustained They wept with her;
but theirs were tears of sympathy. They
sometimes asked, indeed, why their dear
papa staid away SO long, and If he would
never come home, to bring them play things
and claim the compensation OF a kiss again
but when they saw the mother always an
swcred their inquiries with food of tears,
as she clasped them in her arms, they wept
with her again and again. and ceased to ask
these questions, which seemed, they could
scarce tell why, SO painful. She used to
lead them to the grave, often, in the cool and
shadowy evening; and they at last UNDER
stood that their papa lay there, and that he
would, never come back again--and then
their little hearts would swell--but griefisa
transient emotion in the infantile breast.
| Mrs. Granville, however, had still much
to be thankful for. She was left with
comfortable income, many kind friends, and
pretty rural homeland the natural forti-
tuae of her nature in time trumphed over
her grief, and her widowed heart found
comfort in her pretty orphans-round them
her affections clung--and in devoting herself
to their care and education, she again be-
came contented and happy.


think it was about four years after the
loss of her husband, that her eldest child
lovely girl, sickened. She watched by it
day and night, with that intense anxiety,
which, while it pervades the very soul, fears
to entertain suspicion of danger. This
heart suspense was OF long dura-
tion. But the child grew worse and worse,
and she at last received the sad warning to
prepare to give it up She clasped her hand
on her burning brow when she heard it, and
exclaimed Is there indeed danger-can
Cornelia die! But she still clung to one
fond hope---it absorbed every thought--and
cung to it even for a time after the little in-
nocent had closed its weary eyes, and sunk
gently and softly, without a sigh, into its
last long slumbcr. Then she thought size
should never be reconciled to the world a.
gain.--She retired to her chamber when the
funeral obsequies were over, and brooded
over her sorrows, till melancholy blaEched
her cheek, and almost bewildered her heart.
Cornela's little 5yothcr was now left to
wander to the church yard alone, he often
went to her grave beside his fathers He
only distinctly remembered her.-But ere
flower had sufficient time to blossom on
that fresh mound. he was laid in sickness on
the bed from which his departed sister had
, been carried. This reused up the mother
from, i,ep sf,fitrde ,pd al h,r r.. q

From the Trenton Emporium.
TaE WIDOWED MOTHER.

One of the most striking instances OF the
powerful influence of passion is recorded of
young Spanish officer, who being sent up


on a military service to South America, was
stationed at Potos, the governor of which
place made decree, that no Indian should
be employed in carrying the baggage Of Eu-
ropeans. This officer, however, whose
name, was Aeuirra, broke the order, and

continuance, gatlhcation, and enlargement.
feel a satisfaction, which ] know not how to
express, in the innumerable privileges, pleas
ures, and advantages of social and domestic


life, in the interchange of Offices of kindness
ard sympathy with my fellow men, IN the joys
of virtuous friendship, and convivial and intel
lrctual converse, and in the contemplation OF
the immense improvements madeby mankind
il arts and sci noes. and moral worth. adj
mire and would wiah 10 possess that truly
christian spirit Of cohtcntmcrt. gratitude and
b, nevolence, which the venerable Lindsey
exhibited. when at the close OF life OF much
suffering and hardship, he vas able to say with
perfect simplicity and serenity, that even II
there were no life bcvond this, he acknowl
edged himself greatly blessed; and, without
the hope Of a future reunion. yet from the
intercourse aud friendship. which he had en-
joyed with SO many wise and excellent men,
he should depart from life well satisfied
guest. But if had no hope beyond the
present transient scene, know not how
should sustain sorrows, which every day be-
fal me; know not what should support me
under the numerous ard distressing inroads,
which death is daily making in the circle of
nv friends $40 me confess, as one well
describes the effect of death upon the Hea-
! II,
sound, and could not but be attended with
| train of most melancholy reflections. 1t
would unavoi1ably mix with all my enjoy
ments and unavoidably alloy and spoil their
relish. It would be like a sword continual
| " hanging over my head by single hair;
a spectre always haunting my abode; which,
| whatever some libertines might pretend,
would cast a sudden damp on every JOY, and
leave no present ratification free fiom pain
and uncasiness." cannot envy that gloomy
/ scepticsm or that brutal insenslbility, which
regards such events unmoved. | would not
wish to purchase relief with the extinction
of memory, since in the always present rec
objection of departed friends, who deserved
nv respect and affection, find powerful
stimulus to virtue, and satisfaction, though
melancholy, vet most refreshing to my woun-
ded and aching bosom.
! In these sentiments think | utter only
1.-THE sentiment of every virtuons and feeling
heart, What words then can express the
value of a religion, which di,pels all anxiety,
so.icitude, ard grief ~ the departure OF orr
yirtubus and christian friends! what IAN
guagc can express the value OF that blessed
hope, which entereth into that state, which
is beyond the veil OF death; whittier the
forerunner, the guide and prince of life, the
conqueror of death, even Jesus has himself
entered in glory and triumph


| Christian father and mother! when YOU
have deposited in the grave the child of your
affection, and confidence, and hope, perhaps
the son whose virtues, and talents, and man
" qualities were your pride and delight, or
the daughter who clung closely to your
heart, and whose affection and tenderness


you hoped might soften the pangs OF advers-
itv, and cheer the evening OF your lite, tell
me for what you would exchange that bless
ed hope, which after short interval re-
stores them to you. enrobed in celestial
glory, beauty and Immortality. Christian


when you have seen the grave close over the


mortal remains of father, who has been


your guide, and counsellor, and the most


faithful OF friends In your prosperity and ad-


versity, or the kindest of mothers, whose


hope and delight you were, who nurtured
lyour helpless infancy, and so often watched


while you slept, and so often, by her labo-


rious and afiectionate assiduity, soothed the


hours of sickness and pain, and who with so


many prayers and tears, daily approached


Gods mercy seat for your health, happl-


ness, improvement. and salvation, tell me


tor what you would exchange that thrilling


hope, that they rest in peace with that d.


vine Father, who cares tor them with even
more IenQerDeSS tndn rDey Carcu Ior }ou.--


Christian when thy bosom friend has been


snatched from your side, the friend, with


whom you took sweet counsel, and with


whom you walked to the house OF God,


whose sentiments and sympathies were all
yours, whose interests were indssoluoly as
sociated with your own, when YOU have


heard the last affectionate farewell and tax


en- the last look, and caught the last beam OF


Kindness which shot from his closing eyes,


say for what you would exchange the trans


porting hope of reunion in purer friend
lship in better world.


Christians ! speak not to the aged only


but to those, who have just past the morning


of life, when you remark around you the


MANY vacancies which death has made "a


mong those whom you loved, and valued,


when you see how many of TIE aged, and


venerable, and deep-rooted trees have been


upturned, and how many of the fairest open


ing blossoms nipped, how many in their me
redian have been suddenly cut down with


the unripe and ungathered fruit hanging


thick around them, when you have SO often


seen death trampling with indifference on


the pride and boast of genius. wit, and learn


ing, and piercing with his fatal arrow the


thickest shield and panoply of virtue, and
desolating the farest scenes of human hap
piness, usefulness, and promise, tell me have


you never felt the infinite value of that hope
!, Il tf, mi nt

In the north aisle of - Church there is
a small marble tablet, which records the
virtues and perfections of the Rev. Alfred
Corsar, who died August Gath, 1894, aged
twenty nine years. The singular occur
renee, which produced the death of this
young Clergyman, Nehemiah was fond Of re.
lating; and soon after he gave me the ac-
count of his own love adventures, he gratifi-
ed me with the following narrative -


After ! had been CLERK Of this Church a
bout ten years, SAID Nehemiah, the then
Rector became too old and feeble to fulfil his
Clerical duties, and Curate was engaged
to assist him; that Curate was the Rev. Al
fred Corsar, and more worthy or pious
Minister never preached in - Church.
At his first introduction he won the hearts
of all by the Kindness and cheerfulness of his
manners, and by the fervency and devotion
with which he performed the duties of his
Office; but his career was short and fieeting,
and, before he lad been long with us, an
event occurred which blasted his future
hopes, and laid him in an untimely grave


Amongst the female part Of the congre-
cation, was a young Lady named Louisa
Mordaunt, the Daughter OF Gentleman in
easy circumstances, who was at that time
filling the Office Of Church-Warden: 1t was
not long before Alfred Corsar was intro
duced to her, and his visits to her fathers
house became very frequent; strong atfec-
tion arose in his breast, and Louisa Nor.
daunt was its object; but he never had the
courage to avow his love, nor in truth, did
the conduct of Miss Mordanht give him the
least encouragement, so that he continued TO
cherish passion as hopeless asit was fer
vent, without daring to proclaim it to the
world. had some suspicion OF his feelings
from his frequent inquiries respecting Miss
Mordaunt, and was soon dreadfully convin-
ced of the truth OF my surmises, and the cx-
tent Of his love.


Twas sitting ono evening enjoying my nsu-
al beverage at the Griffin, when / received
a message to attend at the church. ! went,
and found stranger writing, who in
formed me that he intended to be married
on the following morning, having obtained a
license from the Rector for that purpose;
of course acouiesced, and inquired the name
Of the latlv;--it was Louisa Mortaunt
vas mitch snrnrised at this, 9s ! had never
before heard Of Miss Elordal.1t having a
lover. but afterwards learned that the Gen
tleman. who now addressed me, had long
been her admirer, though living at distance
-their coultship, which had been carried
on by letters, until her lover found himself
in situation to claim her as his bride, when
she readily consented to bestow her hand
where she had already bestowed her heart,
only stipulatng that the marriage ceremony
should be performed in - Church. Hav-
ing assured the stranger that every thing
should be prepared for the ceremony. he
left the Church, and proceeded to inform
Mr. Corsar that his services would be re-
ouired on the following morning. On being
introduced told him my GRAND. "Well
Nehemiah, said he, and who is the ltady!"
I mentioned Louisa Mordaunt. Nev,r shall
| forget his look at that moment; it was one
| of fixed despair, and he seemed as If his fac
ulties were suspended and his frame wither-
ed by some sudden visitation of Heaven. At
length, by an effort almost superhuman,. he
recovered, and waving his hand, said, "Gc,
go; will attend" / left him, deeply COM
misserating his situation, as ! now found he
indeed loved Louisa Mordaunt.


On the following morning proceeded to
the Church at the hour appointed, and on
entering the Vestry | found Mr.. Corsar
there, but the wedding party had not arriv
cd Mr.. Corsar was standing near the win
dow. absorbed in revcrie, ne looked dread
| fully male and his ewes had a wildness quite
unusual. When he was aware of my pres
ence. he requested me to hand him glass of
wine. which he drank with frightful eager
ness. he requested another, which he drank
with the same avidity, and then sunk OH a
seat quite exhausted. To my enquiries he
returned no answer, but pressed his hand
violently against his forehead At length
the wedding party arrived at the Church,
and after the neceaacry prelimnaries, rang
| ed themselves in order for ceremony; the
Curate left the Nestry without speaking,
and with a slow and faulterng step entered
the Altar; he then commenced the service;
the exordum he gave with sublime effect,
as if he expected his words would con- njure
IN some impeachment TO the marriage, and
when he arrived at that part which says "lt
anv man can show just Cause of impeachment
why these persons may not be lawfully 10
ed together IN wedlock let him now speak,
he paused, and gazed around with look OF
eager expectation,s ,sbut no answer being re
turned, he was compelled to proceed; yet he
seemed to cling to the remainder OF the pas
sage with hopeless tenacty, giving the con-
clusion with sublime and almost terrlhc
energy. The party assembled were aston


shed, and gazed on each other with speech
less amazement, not knowing what to make
of so strange conduct OF the Minister. Al
length he asked the bridegroom the ques-
tion, "NVilt thou have this woman to be thy
welded wifei' &c, to which, OF course, the
answer was 81 will.

From the Kaleidoscope.
THE PARISH CLERK.

full articles.headline:
TFIE MONITOR.

THE CHRISTIANS HOPE.
full articles.article:
"Hope is the medicine Of the soul, the cor


dial which anmates and sustains us under
she labours of life, which alevistes the se-
verest Affections, and which sheds an in
creased splendour over the fairest day Of
earthly prosperity. But the best hopes,
which take their rise only from this world,
and whose flight is restricted within the
narrow range Of earthly good are totally in
adequate to allay the fear of death, and to
remove; or in any measure to mitigate, some
OF the heaviest suff'erings. to which we are
mere subjected. There are disappointments,
which this world cannot compensate; losses,
!or which it can afford no substitute; sor-
rows, to which it brings no alleviation.


would not deny the value and excellence
ef the nature, which God has given me, OF
Ne capacity for Improvement and useful
ness, with which he has cndued me, and the
,,nnumerable sources of qualification and de-
,,lsht, to which he offers me access. ac-
knowledge with gratitude the multiplied
earthly blessings, on his part so undeserved,
which he bestows on me. l am enchanted
with the beauty and splendour, and magnif-
Sehce OF the world in which he has placed
'l,, ane, l rejoice in the fertility of the earth


"llch SO abundantly rewards the labours Of
,,aan, and supplies subsistence for the count
cnissss nss', myrlads of its children. contemplate
11la aslisht the diversified forms of animat-

than the Curate giving one convulsive shud-
der, fell senseless on the Altar. All was
now copfusion-the ceremony was not half
finished, and the Minister was laying sense
less-every means was now used to recover
him, but for some time without effect. At
length he slowly opened his eyes, and the
first object he saw was Louisa Mordaunt,
bending over, him, her looks expressive ofthe
utmost compassion for his situation. This
had almost again plunged him into forgetful-
ness and it was only by very strong effort
that he succeeded in raising himself; he
then, by great exertions, succeeded in finish
ing the ceremony, at the end of which he a.
gain became senseless, and was i'll this state
conveyed home.


He did not long survive the marriage of
Louisa Mordaunt, he soon after died vic
tim OF that worst of all diseases-a broken
heart Louisa Mordaunt lived long and
happily with whom she made her husband
nor did she ever surmise the dreadful effect
her marriage had upon the Rev. Alfred Cor
sar. ]. H.

full articles.headline: MARRIAGE.
full articles.article:
I would fain hear from those marriage
haters but shadow of reason. why | should
not pronounce a modest wife the greatest Of
human blessings. She is the safety of that
house whose affairs she administers. She is
the tender and faithful love Of your children.
She is the JOY of your health, and your care
and relief in sickness, the partner of your
good fortune and comfort in your bad. She
sooths and breaks the headlong violence of
youth, and tempers the morose austerity of
age. Will any one offer to persuade US that
the education of children, which are the ve-
ry images of our bodies and pictures oi our
minds and in whom we see as it were our
very selves born again anew, affords not a
delight since to the last degree' or that is no
satisfaction when we come to obey the laws
of fate, to see son OF our own to whom e
can bequeath those honours and posse ssions
of our families which we received from our
parents.

employed on some expedition an Indian to
Carry his baggage. Ofnis he was instantly
accused, and condemnGd to suffer the pun
ishment enacted for the offence, which was
to be publicly whipped on an ass. Great
intercession was made for him, but without
effect. After many solicitations, however,
respite for fortnight was obtained from the
governor; but just as this reached the prison
the criminal was stript, and mounted, and
exhibited for punishment. On hearing Of
the respite he said. Nay. the shame is suf-
fered; worse cannot be done; therefore, ex-
ecntioner, discharge your duty, and return
the tyrant his reprieve.' The sentence ac-
cordingly took its course, and the young
man endured it with the greatest cslmncss;
but he never after could lie brought t. asso-
ciate with gentlemen. He was constantly
wandering about by himself in a state Of
gloomy melancholy, and stunning the soci-
ETY. and converse of his fellow creatures.


Soon after the Governor was removed,
and another person sent in his stead, but A.
auirra was still seen to hover about the
palace. The Governors friends apprehen-
withdraw to some other place, he did SO,
and went to Los Reyes, three hundred and
twenty leagues from thence; but in a weeks
time Aqyirra was there, having followed
him on foot. The Viceroy then removed as
secretly as he could to Quito, which is four
hundred leagues from Los Reyes; there also
cane Aquirra in a short space oftime, tho
he travelled as before, without shoe& or
stockings. Finding himself SO closely pur-
sued, the Governor took another flight as
far as Cusco, which is FIVE hundred leagues
from Quito, but there also he was followed
by Aqurra. Being wearied by so. many
journeys, the Governor said, Il will fly the
villain no longer, but keep a guard about ms
and defy him;' which he did !; bat the gates
being one day open, and all the servants en-
gagged in play, Aquirra entered, and find
ing his enemy alone, stabbed him to the heart
and then despatched himself with the same
dagger.

full articles.headline:
n e. OLE !: E}s.9 .

From he HaMmeY G Naine Gazettc.
TuELANGuAGE OF THE EYES.
full articles.article:
From he HaAtmeK G. 6Naiae } Gazettc.


THE LANGUAGE OF THE EYES.
There is 4 brightness IN the beam
That darts electric from the eyes,
Softer and dearer than the CLEAN
ORAL that's radient in the skies.
II holds DER every mind control;
II bows each passion to IT'S shrine,
And 6resat once the impassioned soul
Toac.ions generous and divine.
1t language all can speak;
4 tongue all nations understands
o'c, .spland's mountains chill and bleak,
And Ger Arabia's burning sand.
IT is the language foemen speak,
In battles hour Of strife and death;
The peaderfor the dumb and weak,
More powerful far than human breath.
'Tis that which Youthful heroes speak,
when burning blood darts through their veinsi
II is the PATRIOTS, when his check
'.antles TO flame at thought Of cllansi
TIL, lover, when he speaks the tn ought
That bids the maidens bosom rise
Wiz power, with fire, with sweetness iraught,
II is the language q the eyes.


HARLEIGH.

Cold as the grave can make if
That faithful heart must be,
Whose light would not forsakeit
In parting thus from thee.
When hand in hand is warmly prest,
Alasl who docs not know,
That tears swell high in many breast
Too proud to let them flow.
Go--and may every sorrow
BE distant FROM thy way,
And every new tomorrow
Be happier than to-day
My sunshine smile through every storm,
And rainbows through the showers,
While thy mild heaven is clear and warm,
And never cold like ours.
IF innocence and beauty
Concliate human love,
thigh regard for duty
Can find friend above,
No power thy pleasures can destroy,
While love or friendship lives,
And will ask no purer Joy
Than this remembrance gives.

full articles.headline: PROVERBS.
full articles.article:
"d DAB at any IHing."-A dab is consid-
cred to be a mere corruption of the word
adeht, which signifies person far advanc-
ed or perfect in any thing, and is no other
than the word adehtns In the same way a
cute man is the abbreviation of acute, or the
Latin acutus, and signifies person that Is
sharp, clever, neat; or to use more modern
term, an feh, at the subject you happen to
be speaking of.


us Dead as Herriag."--The herring
is delicate fish, which is killed by very
small degree of violence. Whenever it is
taken cut the water, even though it seem to
have received no hurt, it gives squeak, and
Immediately expires; and though it be
thrown instantly back into the water it new
er receives. Hence arises the proverb, "as
dead as herring


"Steehs like Toh."--This we may see
in familiar language of a person completely
under the influence of Morpheus; and we
generally imagine the simile taken from the
momentarv pause of peg-top, or huinming
top, when its rotary motion is at the height.
But no such thing, the werd top is Italian.
Toto, in that language, signifies mouse, 1t
is the generic name, and applied indiscriln-
nately to the common mouse, field mouse,
and dormous, from which the Italian prov
erb, "Ef dorme come an toho" is derived;
Ang};cr, "He clecrs like top"


"Hiac Men d Gotham. ."-Gotham is a
village in Noting ghamshire. Its Magistrates
are said to have attempted to hedge in a
cuckoo; and bush called the Cuckoo's bush,
is still shown in support Of the tradition. A
thousand other ridiculous stories are told Of
the Men of Gotham.


"2rue Blue ner,er Stain. ."--Coventry had
formerly the reputation for dyeing blues; in
somuch that true Blue came to be- proverb,
to signify one who was always the same,
like and himself.


ITO 1Aro7v the Gaatlet"-A proverbitl
phrase sgnifying to challenge or tlefv. The
expression derives its origin from the days
Of c ivalry, when he that challenged an OPP
ponent in the list threw down his glove, and
he that accepted the challenge took it up
The word is Fr, nch, and comes from gand
or gant, glove" The gantlct was in use
before the thirteenth century.


"7o Ran tie Gantlohe.nn-A proverbia
phrase commonly expressed to run the CANT
let, and signfying primarily, a certain mill
itary punishment, and fguratively, the pass
ing through difficulties. According to ths
erroneous pronunciation, the hearcr who
compares this phrase with that which is the
subject of the preceding article, is much al
loss to understand the word gantlef. The
real words are these, "to run the Client
race" Gtent Gauut or Cant is a we'll
known town III Flanders; and iooh in the
Belsic signifies race. The gantlope, oil
Ghent.race, so called because invented al
that place, is this: In the land service whel
soldier is to be punished in this manner
the regiment is drawn out in two ranks, IA
eng ach ether, and each soldier having 3
switch in his hand, lashes the criminal as he
runs along naked from the waist upwards
In the navy, the whole ships crew is dis
posed in two rows, standing face to face, OF
both sides Of the deck, SO as to form line
whereby the delinquent may so forward or
one side and return aft on the other; ant
each seaman being furnished with small
twisted cord, strikes him as he passes.

full articles.headline: Selected for Tie Ultmingtonian.
full articles.article:
Kindly blow, thou ftfill breeze!


Onward roll, thou briny billowi
O'cr the wide and tracklcss seas.


Speed thy course. my gallant U{iloac
Merry landsmsn, free from cares,


Far from din or dread of danger,
Reck MT ofthe toll he bears


Cccan's lorn and lonely ranger
Sport Of whirlwinds giddy breath.


Now on liquid mountains riding,
Forms Of horror, shapes Of death,


Billow, blast and beach bestriding,
Banist'(l far from woman's smile


Smile-the sweetest after sorrow
Far from loves cndearing vile,


Festive eve, and .jocund morrow.
Where The buoyant schooncrridcs,


Perils every track pursuing,
Arms the tempest, swells the tide,


Points the crasgy cliffs with ruin.
Merry landsmen, free from cares,


Far from din or dread Of danger,
Little reck the toll he bears,


Oceans iorn and lonely ranger.

full articles.headline:
From the Trenton Emporium.
TaE WIDOWED MOTHER.
full articles.article:
"oh, mountain streams must ioveler be,
Which, where their waters rise,


Spring On immediate to the sea,


Scarce shown to mortal eyes:


Than those which glide with clouded tide,
Slow o'cT the wastes of earth,


Nor keep one trace of that hign place.


Which gave their pure waves birth"
Mr.. Granville had but recently settled in
Roxborough. and was about commencing
business with aattering prospects of success,
when he was suddenly prostrated by vio-
lent disease against which the natural
strength of his constitution. though in the
prime and yigor of his days, afforded but a
feeble defence. He died the sixth day after
the attack-and they buried him in quiet
corner of the village churchyard, beneath
the shade of young willow, and, as it was
in summer, the fresh turf with which they
decked his grave, soon exhibited a luxurant
vegetation.


A wife and two lovely children were left
behind; and they who have felt what such
bereavement is, alone know something of the
bitterness of the trial which that widowed
mother was called to endure--and to en-
tlure alone; for her infant orphans were too
young to know the full amount of the loss
they had sustained They wept with her;
but theirs were tears of sympathy. They
sometimes asked, indeed, why their dear
papa staid away SO long, and If he would
never come home, to bring them play things
and claim the compensation OF a kiss again
but when they saw the mother always an
swcred their inquiries with food of tears,
as she clasped them in her arms, they wept
with her again and again. and ceased to ask
these questions, which seemed, they could
scarce tell why, SO painful. She used to
lead them to the grave, often, in the cool and
shadowy evening; and they at last UNDER
stood that their papa lay there, and that he
would, never come back again--and then
their little hearts would swell--but griefisa
transient emotion in the infantile breast.
| Mrs. Granville, however, had still much
to be thankful for. She was left with
comfortable income, many kind friends, and
pretty rural homeland the natural forti-
tuae of her nature in time trumphed over
her grief, and her widowed heart found
comfort in her pretty orphans-round them
her affections clung--and in devoting herself
to their care and education, she again be-
came contented and happy.


think it was about four years after the
loss of her husband, that her eldest child
lovely girl, sickened. She watched by it
day and night, with that intense anxiety,
which, while it pervades the very soul, fears
to entertain suspicion of danger. This
heart suspense was OF long dura-
tion. But the child grew worse and worse,
and she at last received the sad warning to
prepare to give it up She clasped her hand
on her burning brow when she heard it, and
exclaimed Is there indeed danger-can
Cornelia die! But she still clung to one
fond hope---it absorbed every thought--and
cung to it even for a time after the little in-
nocent had closed its weary eyes, and sunk
gently and softly, without a sigh, into its
last long slumbcr. Then she thought size
should never be reconciled to the world a.
gain.--She retired to her chamber when the
funeral obsequies were over, and brooded
over her sorrows, till melancholy blaEched
her cheek, and almost bewildered her heart.
Cornela's little 5yothcr was now left to
wander to the church yard alone, he often
went to her grave beside his fathers He
only distinctly remembered her.-But ere
flower had sufficient time to blossom on
that fresh mound. he was laid in sickness on
the bed from which his departed sister had
, been carried. This reused up the mother
from, i,ep sf,fitrde ,pd al h,r r.. q

One of the most striking instances OF the
powerful influence of passion is recorded of
young Spanish officer, who being sent up


on a military service to South America, was
stationed at Potos, the governor of which
place made decree, that no Indian should
be employed in carrying the baggage Of Eu-
ropeans. This officer, however, whose
name, was Aeuirra, broke the order, and

continuance, gatlhcation, and enlargement.
feel a satisfaction, which ] know not how to
express, in the innumerable privileges, pleas
ures, and advantages of social and domestic


life, in the interchange of Offices of kindness
ard sympathy with my fellow men, IN the joys
of virtuous friendship, and convivial and intel
lrctual converse, and in the contemplation OF
the immense improvements madeby mankind
il arts and sci noes. and moral worth. adj
mire and would wiah 10 possess that truly
christian spirit Of cohtcntmcrt. gratitude and
b, nevolence, which the venerable Lindsey
exhibited. when at the close OF life OF much
suffering and hardship, he vas able to say with
perfect simplicity and serenity, that even II
there were no life bcvond this, he acknowl
edged himself greatly blessed; and, without
the hope Of a future reunion. yet from the
intercourse aud friendship. which he had en-
joyed with SO many wise and excellent men,
he should depart from life well satisfied
guest. But if had no hope beyond the
present transient scene, know not how
should sustain sorrows, which every day be-
fal me; know not what should support me
under the numerous ard distressing inroads,
which death is daily making in the circle of
nv friends $40 me confess, as one well
describes the effect of death upon the Hea-
! II,
sound, and could not but be attended with
| train of most melancholy reflections. 1t
would unavoi1ably mix with all my enjoy
ments and unavoidably alloy and spoil their
relish. It would be like a sword continual
| " hanging over my head by single hair;
a spectre always haunting my abode; which,
| whatever some libertines might pretend,
would cast a sudden damp on every JOY, and
leave no present ratification free fiom pain
and uncasiness." cannot envy that gloomy
/ scepticsm or that brutal insenslbility, which
regards such events unmoved. | would not
wish to purchase relief with the extinction
of memory, since in the always present rec
objection of departed friends, who deserved
nv respect and affection, find powerful
stimulus to virtue, and satisfaction, though
melancholy, vet most refreshing to my woun-
ded and aching bosom.
! In these sentiments think | utter only
1.-THE sentiment of every virtuons and feeling
heart, What words then can express the
value of a religion, which di,pels all anxiety,
so.icitude, ard grief ~ the departure OF orr
yirtubus and christian friends! what IAN
guagc can express the value OF that blessed
hope, which entereth into that state, which
is beyond the veil OF death; whittier the
forerunner, the guide and prince of life, the
conqueror of death, even Jesus has himself
entered in glory and triumph


| Christian father and mother! when YOU
have deposited in the grave the child of your
affection, and confidence, and hope, perhaps
the son whose virtues, and talents, and man
" qualities were your pride and delight, or
the daughter who clung closely to your
heart, and whose affection and tenderness


you hoped might soften the pangs OF advers-
itv, and cheer the evening OF your lite, tell
me for what you would exchange that bless
ed hope, which after short interval re-
stores them to you. enrobed in celestial
glory, beauty and Immortality. Christian


when you have seen the grave close over the


mortal remains of father, who has been


your guide, and counsellor, and the most


faithful OF friends In your prosperity and ad-


versity, or the kindest of mothers, whose


hope and delight you were, who nurtured
lyour helpless infancy, and so often watched


while you slept, and so often, by her labo-


rious and afiectionate assiduity, soothed the


hours of sickness and pain, and who with so


many prayers and tears, daily approached


Gods mercy seat for your health, happl-


ness, improvement. and salvation, tell me


tor what you would exchange that thrilling


hope, that they rest in peace with that d.


vine Father, who cares tor them with even
more IenQerDeSS tndn rDey Carcu Ior }ou.--


Christian when thy bosom friend has been


snatched from your side, the friend, with


whom you took sweet counsel, and with


whom you walked to the house OF God,


whose sentiments and sympathies were all
yours, whose interests were indssoluoly as
sociated with your own, when YOU have


heard the last affectionate farewell and tax


en- the last look, and caught the last beam OF


Kindness which shot from his closing eyes,


say for what you would exchange the trans


porting hope of reunion in purer friend
lship in better world.


Christians ! speak not to the aged only


but to those, who have just past the morning


of life, when you remark around you the


MANY vacancies which death has made "a


mong those whom you loved, and valued,


when you see how many of TIE aged, and


venerable, and deep-rooted trees have been


upturned, and how many of the fairest open


ing blossoms nipped, how many in their me
redian have been suddenly cut down with


the unripe and ungathered fruit hanging


thick around them, when you have SO often


seen death trampling with indifference on


the pride and boast of genius. wit, and learn


ing, and piercing with his fatal arrow the


thickest shield and panoply of virtue, and
desolating the farest scenes of human hap
piness, usefulness, and promise, tell me have


you never felt the infinite value of that hope
!, Il tf, mi nt

full articles.headline:
From the Kaleidoscope.
THE PARISH CLERK.
full articles.article:
In the north aisle of - Church there is
a small marble tablet, which records the
virtues and perfections of the Rev. Alfred
Corsar, who died August Gath, 1894, aged
twenty nine years. The singular occur
renee, which produced the death of this
young Clergyman, Nehemiah was fond Of re.
lating; and soon after he gave me the ac-
count of his own love adventures, he gratifi-
ed me with the following narrative -


After ! had been CLERK Of this Church a
bout ten years, SAID Nehemiah, the then
Rector became too old and feeble to fulfil his
Clerical duties, and Curate was engaged
to assist him; that Curate was the Rev. Al
fred Corsar, and more worthy or pious
Minister never preached in - Church.
At his first introduction he won the hearts
of all by the Kindness and cheerfulness of his
manners, and by the fervency and devotion
with which he performed the duties of his
Office; but his career was short and fieeting,
and, before he lad been long with us, an
event occurred which blasted his future
hopes, and laid him in an untimely grave


Amongst the female part Of the congre-
cation, was a young Lady named Louisa
Mordaunt, the Daughter OF Gentleman in
easy circumstances, who was at that time
filling the Office Of Church-Warden: 1t was
not long before Alfred Corsar was intro
duced to her, and his visits to her fathers
house became very frequent; strong atfec-
tion arose in his breast, and Louisa Nor.
daunt was its object; but he never had the
courage to avow his love, nor in truth, did
the conduct of Miss Mordanht give him the
least encouragement, so that he continued TO
cherish passion as hopeless asit was fer
vent, without daring to proclaim it to the
world. had some suspicion OF his feelings
from his frequent inquiries respecting Miss
Mordaunt, and was soon dreadfully convin-
ced of the truth OF my surmises, and the cx-
tent Of his love.


Twas sitting ono evening enjoying my nsu-
al beverage at the Griffin, when / received
a message to attend at the church. ! went,
and found stranger writing, who in
formed me that he intended to be married
on the following morning, having obtained a
license from the Rector for that purpose;
of course acouiesced, and inquired the name
Of the latlv;--it was Louisa Mortaunt
vas mitch snrnrised at this, 9s ! had never
before heard Of Miss Elordal.1t having a
lover. but afterwards learned that the Gen
tleman. who now addressed me, had long
been her admirer, though living at distance
-their coultship, which had been carried
on by letters, until her lover found himself
in situation to claim her as his bride, when
she readily consented to bestow her hand
where she had already bestowed her heart,
only stipulatng that the marriage ceremony
should be performed in - Church. Hav-
ing assured the stranger that every thing
should be prepared for the ceremony. he
left the Church, and proceeded to inform
Mr. Corsar that his services would be re-
ouired on the following morning. On being
introduced told him my GRAND. "Well
Nehemiah, said he, and who is the ltady!"
I mentioned Louisa Mordaunt. Nev,r shall
| forget his look at that moment; it was one
| of fixed despair, and he seemed as If his fac
ulties were suspended and his frame wither-
ed by some sudden visitation of Heaven. At
length, by an effort almost superhuman,. he
recovered, and waving his hand, said, "Gc,
go; will attend" / left him, deeply COM
misserating his situation, as ! now found he
indeed loved Louisa Mordaunt.


On the following morning proceeded to
the Church at the hour appointed, and on
entering the Vestry | found Mr.. Corsar
there, but the wedding party had not arriv
cd Mr.. Corsar was standing near the win
dow. absorbed in revcrie, ne looked dread
| fully male and his ewes had a wildness quite
unusual. When he was aware of my pres
ence. he requested me to hand him glass of
wine. which he drank with frightful eager
ness. he requested another, which he drank
with the same avidity, and then sunk OH a
seat quite exhausted. To my enquiries he
returned no answer, but pressed his hand
violently against his forehead At length
the wedding party arrived at the Church,
and after the neceaacry prelimnaries, rang
| ed themselves in order for ceremony; the
Curate left the Nestry without speaking,
and with a slow and faulterng step entered
the Altar; he then commenced the service;
the exordum he gave with sublime effect,
as if he expected his words would con- njure
IN some impeachment TO the marriage, and
when he arrived at that part which says "lt
anv man can show just Cause of impeachment
why these persons may not be lawfully 10
ed together IN wedlock let him now speak,
he paused, and gazed around with look OF
eager expectation,s ,sbut no answer being re
turned, he was compelled to proceed; yet he
seemed to cling to the remainder OF the pas
sage with hopeless tenacty, giving the con-
clusion with sublime and almost terrlhc
energy. The party assembled were aston


shed, and gazed on each other with speech
less amazement, not knowing what to make
of so strange conduct OF the Minister. Al
length he asked the bridegroom the ques-
tion, "NVilt thou have this woman to be thy
welded wifei' &c, to which, OF course, the
answer was 81 will.
